Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
CAN: The student might be able to illustrate the material before heating or cooling, like a basic representation of ice and an egg.
The student might show some primitive indication of change occurring, such as squiggly lines around the materials (attempt to show heating).
CANNOT: The student is unlikely to correctly depict the material after heating or cooling (e.g., may draw the ice unchanged after melting or the egg looking the same after cooking *student does not understand changes*).
The student cannot accurately show whether the change can be reversed (may draw cooked egg as unchanged or not return melted ice to cube form *misunderstanding reversibility*).

The student cannot identify in the drawing if the change is irreversible, possibly showing ice becoming water with no distinction from the egg cooking diagram (*student does not grasp irreversible concept*).

The student might fail to clearly highlight in the drawing the cause of the change, such as merely drawing arrows without labeling or misplacing them entirely (*misunderstanding of cause and effect*).
The student might not be able to illustrate or may incorrectly attempt a comparison of reversible vs. irreversible changes, such as mixing examples or labels (*no clear comprehension of comparison*).
